node.title: Cond√© Nast Knows Faded Glory Is Not in Style
node.alt: From left, Agnes Chu, the president of Condé Nast entertainment; Anna Wintour, the global chief content officer for Condé Nast and editor of U.S. Vogue; and Roger Lynch, Condé Nast’s chief executive.
node.description: Anna Wintour is the embodiment of the glory days of the magazine dynasty. Now she is pitching its global, digital future.
node.content: ["Anna Wintour, the top editor of Vogue since 1988, known for her iconic bob and perma-sunglasses and exacting taste, is in many ways the embodiment of Cond\u00e9 Nast\u2019s lavish history as an arbiter of style. Now she\u2019s selling its future, where the editor in chief role she helped define is a relic, and the company operates by a code that includes the maxim: \u201cExceptional does not mean exclusive.\u201d", "\u201cI think what\u2019s so wonderful about working in media is the constant change and seeing things move,\u201d Ms. Wintour said in an interview in Cond\u00e9 Nast\u2019s largely empty 1 World Trade Center offices in Manhattan. \u201cParticularly today when it moves so fast. Yeah, it was great then, but what\u2019s happening in the future is greater still.\u201d", "Some Cond\u00e9 Nast employees weren\u2019t sure Ms. Wintour should be a part of that future. In June 2020, workers asked at an all-company meeting if she was leaving the company. She had just apologized for her role in a culture that many said sidelined people of color, amid a broader reckoning with race and diversity across the company and the media industry.", "Ms. Wintour was not going anywhere. Since then, she has been promoted to global chief content officer and is presiding over a sweeping transformation of the company as executives try to shrug off its legacy as the pre-eminent magazine publisher of the last century, when it burnished its brand of elitism and spared no expense on its titles.", "On a crisp fall day, I met with Ms. Wintour (sunglasses on) and Roger Lynch, Cond\u00e9 Nast\u2019s chief executive, to hear their vision for the New Cond\u00e9.", "The stakes for getting it right go beyond just the company\u2019s financial survival. As well as the existential angst for all old media titans of whether it is possible to remain relevant, there is a bigger question: Can Cond\u00e9 Nast, under pressure, take real steps to address both a culture that many employees described as a difficult place for people of color to succeed and content that has in the past elevated a Eurocentric standard of beauty? Can an institution that thrived on paying great attention to the superficial make a deeper-than-surface-level change?", "It has undoubtedly been a tough time for the magazine business. Print advertising has cratered in the past 15 years, and audiences no longer look primarily to legacy brands to tell them what is fashionable. In recent years, Cond\u00e9 Nast\u2019s U.S. business had been losing more than $100 million annually.", "In 2018, Cond\u00e9 Nast announced that it was combining its U.S. business with its sister company, Cond\u00e9 Nast International, to create a global company. The two businesses had previously operated almost completely separately from each other, with Vogue magazines in Europe or GQ editions in Asia having little to do with their American counterparts. Publications often competed with each other for the same advertisers and cover stars. Mr. Lynch was appointed the global chief executive in 2019 to oversee the merger, which would consolidate back-end operations to save money.", "\u201cRoger faced a company that was in a really difficult revenue situation,\u201d said Steven Newhouse, the chairman of Cond\u00e9 Nast\u2019s parent company, Advance Publications, and a member of the billionaire family that has owned Advance for nearly 100 years.", "\u201cUnless we want to look like a museum, we had to change and change pretty radically,\u201d he added.", "For the past year, Ms. Wintour has been focused on the next step of the process: turning seven of Cond\u00e9 Nast\u2019s biggest publications \u2014 Vogue, GQ, Wired, Architectural Digest, Vanity Fair, Cond\u00e9 Nast Traveler and Glamour \u2014 into global brands, each under one leader, cutting costs and streamlining the sharing of content across both print magazines and digital platforms.", "\u201cInstead of having 27 Vogues or 10 Vogues go after one story, we have one global Vogue go after it,\u201d Ms. Wintour said. \u201cSo it\u2019s more like a global newsroom with different hubs.\u201d", "The switch in focus from local to global has not gone down well everywhere. Tina Brown, the former editor of The New Yorker and Vanity Fair, filleted the plan as \u201csuicidal\u201d in an interview in August with The Times of London.", "\u201cObviously there are some stories that work, particularly if you think about fashion, that\u2019s a global language, and music, so there are stories that will work across all territories and then those that absolutely won\u2019t,\u201d Ms. Wintour said. \u201cWe\u2019re very aware of that.\u201d", "Ms. Wintour is also ensuring that there are unlikely to be any more Anna Wintours \u2014 no more imperial editors in chief each with their own fiefs, a job Ms. Wintour herself helped create as a stylish but exacting gatekeeper of fashion and culture. The brands are now run by \u201cglobal editorial directors,\u201d most of whom are based in New York, with regional heads of content reporting to them.", "\u201cBefore, you created stories for publication and it came out once a month and that was great,\u201d she said, describing the old domain of an editor in chief. Now the global editorial directors and heads of content are working across platforms that include \u201cdigital, video, short and long form, social, events, philanthropic endeavors, membership, consumer, e-commerce,\u201d Ms. Wintour said.", "\u201cYou touch so many different worlds,\u201d she added. \u201cHonestly, who wouldn\u2019t want that job?\u201d", "In the midst of the change at Cond\u00e9 Nast, plenty of people decided they didn\u2019t.", "A parade of veteran Cond\u00e9 Nast editors in chief have departed the company in the past 12 months, including Vogue Paris\u2019s Emmanuelle Alt (10 years), Vogue China\u2019s Angelica Cheung (16 years), Vogue Germany\u2019s Christiane Arp (17 years) and British GQ\u2019s Dylan Jones (22 years). Michelle Lee of Allure and Whembley Sewell of Them, an L.G.B.T.Q.-focused website, both went to jobs at Netflix. Lindsay Peoples Wagner, the editor in chief of Teen Vogue and a rising star in the company, left in January for New York Magazine\u2019s The Cut.", "\u201cWe have nothing but great respect for the editors that have worked with us for many years,\u201d Ms. Wintour said when asked about the mass exodus. \u201cSome of them decided to move on and weren\u2019t as comfortable with the transition as some of the others, but we \u2014 you know, it is time to change the company and to have modern thinking.\u201d", "In large part, Cond\u00e9 Nast executives are trying desperately to move away from the lavish glory days of years past. No one wants to dwell on the town cars, or the epic expense accounts, or the legions of assistants.", "Ms. Wintour professes no lingering wistfulness \u2014 leading by example by being the one to bid Old Cond\u00e9 farewell. But, when getting into the question of the good old days vs. now, some nostalgia creeps in. She recalled the recent appointment of Hamish Bowles to the top job at World of Interiors, Cond\u00e9 Nast\u2019s influential design magazine.", "\u201cWhat struck me when I was thinking about who we might put in that role is that that is a title that people archive and keep, it\u2019s the best quality, it\u2019s incredible paper, it\u2019s like the standard-bearer for that particular world,\u201d she said.", "\u201cI feel that print is our runway,\u201d she said, adding: \u201cIt should be collectible. It should be something that you want to hold on to.\u201d", "But the print days are mostly over: Mr. Lynch described the company to me as a \u201cmajority digital business,\u201d with more money coming in from digital ads than print. But he\u2019s eager to lessen the reliance on advertising of any kind and grow different revenue streams. Currently, a majority of Cond\u00e9 Nast\u2019s revenue is from advertising, with consumer revenue (which means subscriptions, memberships and e-commerce) making up about 25 percent.", "And so, the company has pushed further into video. Last year, it hired Agnes Chu away from Disney to head its Cond\u00e9 Nast Entertainment division, with a mandate to ramp up its film and television team and create more digital videos with the global brands.", "Ms. Chu said her strategy centered on subtitling English-language content for global distribution and creating or adapting region-specific content that could have broader appeal. She pointed to the success of Architectural Digest\u2019s \u201cOpen Door\u201d home tour video series, where a recent episode featuring the Indian actress Sonam Kapoor Ahuja got 12 million views across all social media platforms, with a third coming from outside of India.", "But production is an expensive business and huge successes from the entertainment arm have been relatively limited. ", "The executives pointed to the coverage of September\u2019s Met Gala as a successful execution of their strategy: Video of celebrity arrivals at the event, a fund-raising benefit for the Metropolitan Museum of Art that has been organized by Ms. Wintour for nearly 30 years, was live streamed by Vogue for the first time, thanks to the video-providing capabilities of Cond\u00e9 Nast Entertainment. It had nearly 15 million viewers on Vogue.com and its Twitter account, the executives said, while additional Met Gala content got more than 200 million views across social media.", "The executives also mentioned having the ability to now execute worldwide social media plans to distribute interviews and fashion shoots with celebrities that have global appeal, like GQ\u2019s November profile of Will Smith or Adele\u2019s cover of both the U.S. and U.K. issues of Vogue the same month.", "Ultimately, the new strategy may sound a lot like translating the hits of the past for the World Wide Web, suggesting the sluggishness with which the company has adapted its magazines to a digital world.", "Janice Min, a media executive and the former top editor of The Hollywood Reporter and Us Weekly, said that Cond\u00e9 Nast and similar publications were trying to strike a balance between having enough scale to compete with Google and Facebook for advertisers, and having the \u201cright\u201d audience to attract those advertisers.", "\u201cI think without the whiff of elitism, that sort of old-school top-down approach to telling the world what to wear and think, Cond\u00e9 Nast runs the risk of becoming just another white-label content farm on the web,\u201d she said. \u201cHow do you stay special and distinct and in a world that demands equity?\u201d", "Cond\u00e9 Nast says it is taking equity seriously. Ms. Wintour pointed to the shake-up in editorial ranks as an opportunity to promote new leaders with diverse perspectives, such as Margaret Zhang, who now leads Vogue China, or Adam Baidawi, the deputy global editorial director of GQ.", "\u201cI\u2019m an Iraqi that grew up in the southern suburbs of Melbourne, Australia,\u201d Mr. Baidawi said in a video interview. \u201cAnd how many Iraqi surnames do you think I saw on the mastheads of brands I loved, or vaguely Middle Eastern surnames even?\u201d", "He was enthusiastic about the more collaborative way of working, saying diverse perspectives were \u201cliterally baked in\u201d because people from all over the world were contributing and debating ideas.", "\u201cIt\u2019s not said enough that a lack of diversity is boring as hell,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re in a creative business, and more diversity means better ideas.\u201d", "Mr. Baidawi said Cond\u00e9 Nast was now operating in a much more modern way.", "\u201cMy entire career, everywhere I\u2019ve gone, people have told me that I\u2019ve missed this wildly romanticized golden era of luxury media: \u2018Adam, there were town cars, private jets, and there were reshoot budgets,\u2019\u201d he said, adding, \u201cFrankly, I\u2019m not interested in chasing ghosts or recreating old glory.\u201d", "Leslie Sun, Vogue\u2019s editorial lead for the Asia Pacific region, said she saw the new Cond\u00e9 Nast as \u201calmost like a new dynasty,\u201d and a chance for her to draw attention to her region.", "\u201cOf course, we all know that it is simply not true that culture is born out of the U.S. or Europe alone, or that one country would define art or fashion or culture for the rest of the world,\u201d she said.", "The company introduced \u201cThe Cond\u00e9 Code\u201d in September 2020, a five-pronged set of values that states that \u201cdiversity is our strength,\u201d as part of its efforts within the company to address the concerns over racism. Around the same time, a global chief diversity and inclusion officer, Yashica Olden, was hired and the company released its first diversity report. (A spokeswoman said a second report would be released early next year. Nearly 40 percent of the company\u2019s new hires in 2020 and almost half of the top editors in the United States are people of color, the spokeswoman added.)", "At the same time, employees across the company are pushing for broader change. Four publications \u2014 The New Yorker, Wired, Ars Technica and Pitchfork \u2014 formed unions in the last couple of years with the NewsGuild, which also represents employees at The New York Times and other media organizations. Cond\u00e9 Nast recently reached a deal on a contract with three of the unions after heated and public negotiations, which included a protest outside of Ms. Wintour\u2019s Greenwich Village townhouse.", "Now, staff members at the remaining publications, including Vogue, are organizing and plan to announce soon that they are forming a union, according to two current Cond\u00e9 Nast staff members and one former employee.", "Cond\u00e9 Nast\u2019s new strategy is deeply rooted in the financial headwinds the company is facing. Mr. Lynch says the plan is working, and shared new numbers to prove it. The company will break even in 2021, a year ahead of schedule, he said, and is on track to be profitable by 2023. This was partly driven by a spike in digital advertising revenue, which grew 56 percent year-over-year in the third quarter this year, he added.", "According to a person familiar with the financial details of the company, U.S. revenue is expected to exceed $1 billion this year, up nearly $150 million from the previous year. Mr. Lynch said his plan included a 25 percent increase in investment in journalism and content production.", "\u201cOur plans have us investing more in content, not less. But the way we fund at least part of that is we eliminate things that didn\u2019t add value to audiences or advertisers,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was just duplication of costs.\u201d", "Mr. Newhouse, the chairman, said that Advance was excited about the progress Mr. Lynch had made with his strategy, and that there was no interest in selling Cond\u00e9 Nast.", "\u201cWe have a very thoughtful and compelling plan that takes us to 2026 and we\u2019re prepared to execute against it,\u201d he said, adding that part of the plan included \u201clooking at acquisitions, partnerships, all things that require capital.\u201d", "As Cond\u00e9 Nast\u2019s employees start trickling back in to their offices, a return that is currently voluntary, they\u2019ll encounter a company structured completely differently than it was before the pandemic. And they will see Ms. Wintour, who, at 72, has outlasted every rumor of an impending departure from her post, has consolidated power and is in the office almost every day.", "\u201cRight now, I\u2019m focused on today,\u201d she said, when asked if she planned to leave the company any time soon.", "\u201cShe\u2019s not allowed to retire before me,\u201d Mr. Lynch interrupted, laughing."]
